channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lebanon’s Hospitals Buckle Amid Israel’s Offensive Against Hezbollah
item.description: The United Nations says “the targeting of health and relief operations is broadening” in Lebanon. Hospitals say they have been forced to close or are struggling to operate.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I don’t want to close the hospital,” said Elie Hachem, director of St. Therese Hospital, on the outskirts of Beirut, that has been damaged by airstrikes. “The community needs us.”

item.title: What To Know About India and Canada’s Diplomatic Rift
item.description: The diplomatic rift has suddenly grown more stark as Canada amplifies its accusations that India is directing lethal operations abroad.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Dave Chan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday accused the Indian government of orchestrating homicide and extortion in Canada.

item.title: Political Infighting Hampers Ukraine’s Efforts to Avert Energy Crisis
item.description: Top energy officials have fallen and key energy policy decisions have been delayed because of political calculations, lawmakers and experts say, costing Ukraine valuable time in preparing for winter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed transformers and power lines at a power plant in Kurakhove, Ukraine, in March.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Comedians Are Using Political Satire to Laugh Amid the Pain
item.description: A generation that fled political persecution and economic hardship is finding a way to laugh amid the pain.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Estefanía León, a Venezuelan comedian living in Mexico City, is part of the comedy troupe El Cuartico.

item.title: China’s Wild Panda Census is Widely Regarded as Flawed
item.description: The panda census methodology is widely seen as flawed, and China keeps the data shrouded in secrecy.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors photographing a panda in August at the Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding in China.

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s Accusations Spotlight Reach of India’s Intelligence Agencies
item.description: The Canadian prime minster’s accusation of Indian government involvement in the killing of a Sikh nationalist signifies a sharp escalation in diplomatic tensions between India and Canada.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Maxim Shipenkov
item.media:description: The most senior official in the intelligence and national security apparatus is Ajit Doval, India’s national security adviser.

item.title: Hanni of NewJeans Testifies in Parliament About Bullying at Work
item.description: The appearance by Hanni, a member of NewJeans, was eagerly awaited, but she offered few revelations about her famously regimented industry.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Kim Min-Hee/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The appearance of Hanni, a member of NewJeans, at the National Assembly in Seoul had been eagerly awaited.

item.title: 9 Monkeys Die in a Hong Kong Zoo
item.description: The zoo partially closed after the deaths, which occurred over two days and included members of a critically endangered species.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Raymond Asia Photography, via Alamy
item.media:description: Watching monkeys at the Hong Kong Zoological and Botanical Gardens in 2017.

item.title: 50 Years After Killing, a Berlin Court Convicts a Stasi Officer of Murder
item.description: The court handed down a guilty verdict and a 10-year sentence to a former officer of East Germany’s dreaded secret police, in a case straight out of the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Sebastian Gollnow/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Manfred Naumann, a former officer of East Germany’s secret police, covered his face in court on Monday during his sentencing in Berlin.

item.title: Tent Camp in Gaza Engulfed by Flames After Israeli Strike
item.description: At least four Palestinians taking shelter by a hospital were killed in a strike Israeli officials said was targeting a Hamas command center.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Abdel Kareem Hana/Associated Press
item.media:description: The scene after an Israeli strike caused a deadly fire in a tent encampment at a hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Monday.

item.title: How Israel’s Army Uses Palestinians as Human Shields in Gaza
item.description: Israeli soldiers and Palestinian former detainees say troops have regularly forced captured Gazans to carry out life-threatening tasks, including inside Hamas tunnels.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer, Bilal Shbair and Patrick Kingsley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers during a military tour for journalists of a tunnel under a U.N. site in Gaza. The Times later found that a Palestinian had been forced to explore the tunnel.

item.title: Italy Sends Boat to Albania With Migrants Who Were Bound for Italian Shores
item.description: The plan was heralded by the Italian government as an innovative model to manage and deter immigration, and criticized by human rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Florion Goga/Reuters
item.media:description: A detention center for migrants seeking to enter Italy, in Gjader, Albania, last week.

item.title: Iranian General Is Seen in State Media After Questions Over His Whereabouts
item.description: Brig. Gen. Esmail Ghaani, commander of the elite Quds Force, appeared in video footage on Tuesday as Tehran braces for a possible counterstrike by Israel.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Devastating Israeli strikes in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mohammed Saber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Palestinians surveyed the damage at a camp for displaced people on the grounds of Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in central Gaza after an Israeli strike on Monday.

item.title: Therapeutic Food Shortage Puts African Children at Risk of Starvation, U.N. Agency Says
item.description: Supplies of a highly nutritious treatment are running out, according to UNICEF.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fatuma Adoum, a refugee from Sudan, with one of her infant twin daughters at a malnutrition center run by Doctors Without Borders in Adre, Chad, in July.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: India Accused of Homicide and Extortion
item.description: Plus, an artist sues to reclaim his work.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Blair Gable/Reuters
item.media:description: Sanjay Kumar Verma, India’s top diplomat in Canada, in June.

item.title: Survivors of Al Aqsa Hospital Fire in Gaza Say They Are Living a ‘Recurring Nightmare’
item.description: Scores of families sheltering outside Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital say they have survived a string of Israeli strikes on the compound and feel trapped with nowhere to go.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Abdel Kareem Hana/Associated Press
item.media:description: Palestinians in the courtyard of Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al Balah, central Gaza, after the deadly attack on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Sends THAAD Missile Defense System to Israel: What to Know
item.description: It can intercept missiles above Earth’s atmosphere, and is being deployed to defend against Iranian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Terminal High Altitude Area Defense unit deployed last year in Guam during a multinational joint military exercise.

item.title: In Jordan, a ‘Stunning’ Discovery Under Petra’s Ancient Stone
item.description: A recent excavation has unearthed 12 human skeletons and a chamber of grave offerings near Petra’s Treasury building, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Discovery's Expedition Unknown
item.media:description: From left, the archaeologist Matthew Vincent, the television host Josh Gates, and a professor, Pearce Paul Creasman, digging in front of the Treasury building in Petra.

item.title: Deadly Hezbollah Attack Shows Israel’s Weakness Against Drones
item.description: Israel has one of the world’s best defenses against missiles and rockets, but struggles to detect slower-moving unmanned aircraft, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military facilities near the site of a drone attack outside Binyamina, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling Means Italy’s ‘Bunga Bunga’ Saga Is Not Over
item.description: The ruling sets the stage for yet another trial related to the scandal involving Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy who died last year.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Luca Bruno/Associated Press
item.media:description: Italy’s Supreme Court overturned acquittals from a lower court, ruling on Monday that women accused of helping to cover up Silvio Berlusconi’s evening bacchanals could be retried.

item.title: Canada Expels Indian Diplomats, Claiming They Were Part of a Criminal Network
item.description: The Canadian police said the Indian government had orchestrated homicides and extortion in Canada to intimidate Sikh separatists. India, in return, kicked out Canadian diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
item.media:description: Sikh protesters in British Columbia, in September 2023.

item.title: Russia Is Winning Back Territory Taken by Ukraine in Its Summer Offensive
item.description: Moscow’s forces have been recapturing some villages and land taken in a Ukrainian incursion into Russia. The advances could undermine Kyiv’s hopes of pushing Russia to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian army vehicles pass by a sign which reads “Ukraine” (left) and “Russia” (right) on a Russian road near a destroyed border post in August.

item.title: Nobel Economics Prize Awarded to Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson and James Robinson
item.description: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson and James Robinson shared the award for their work on explaining the gaps in prosperity between nations.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Christine Olsson/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Swedish Academy of Sciences announcing the 2024 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in Stockholm on Monday.

item.title: Russian Oil Flows Through Western ‘Price Cap’ as Shadow Fleet Grows
item.description: A report shows how Russia has largely evaded sanctions aimed at limiting its revenue from oil sales.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Russian Disinformation Targets U.S.-Backed Anti-Malaria Campaign
item.description: Scientists fighting the spread of infectious diseases on the continent have been targeted online by pro-Russian activists, part of an effort to spread fear and mistrust of the West.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Guerchom Ndebo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Souleymane Sankara, an entomologist with Target Malaria, in Bobo-Dioulasso, Burkina Faso.

item.title: A French Immersion Program in Provence Leads to a Good Life Lesson
item.description: After a painful breakup, the author travels to Provence for a language immersion homestay and learns the value of facing up to mistakes.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Gwen Keraval

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A Hezbollah attack on an Israeli military base.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Amir Levy/Getty Images
item.media:description: Securing a road in Binyamina, Israel, after a drone attack on Sunday.

item.title: China Holds War Games Encircling Taiwan in Warning to Island’s Leader
item.description: Scores of Chinese aircraft and dozens of ships surrounded Taiwan, after President Lai Ching-te rejected Beijing’s claim over the island.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Annabelle Chih/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te speaking in Taipei, Taiwan’s capital, on Thursday, its National Day. He said China and Taiwan were “not subordinate to each other.”

item.title: Just Over the Border from Israel, a Hezbollah Cache of Explosives and Mines
item.description: Israel’s military showed journalists parts of what it said was Hezbollah’s deeply entrenched military infrastructure across the border in southern Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Isabel Kershner/The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers lead a group of journalists along a trail in southern Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: The U.S. to Deploy Troops to Israel
item.description: Plus, 200,000 stories of Modern Love.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Terminal High Altitude Area Defense system in Guam in 2023.

item.title: U.S. to Deploy Missile Defense System and About 100 Troops to Israel
item.description: The Pentagon announced it would send the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense battery and its crew as Israel considered retaliatory attacks against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Terminal High Altitude Area Defense system in Guam in 2023.

item.title: Israeli Jets Pummel Hezbollah Targets in Southern Lebanon
item.description: The strike, which wounded dozens, showed that the militant group remains a force.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Aaron Boxerman, Johnatan Reiss and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military facilities near the site of a drone attack outside Binyamina, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Can the Government Get People to Have More Babies?
item.description: Japan has been trying to boost its fertility rate for 30 years. Now the rest of the rich world is, too.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

item.title: Jokes and Offbeat Auctions for the Troops: Standup Comedy Sweeps Ukraine
item.description: Even as the conflict with Russia grinds on, a new generation of comics in Ukraine is trying to make people laugh — and raise money for the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anton Tymoshenko performing at a stand-up comedy show in July in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Strikes on Ukrainian Ports Target Civilian Shipping
item.description: With the strikes in the Odesa region, Russia appears to be trying again to prevent Ukraine from exporting grain, harming its economy and pushing up world prices.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Port of Odesa in March. Russia has intensified its strikes on the region recently.

item.title: Ladakh’s Local Hero Wants India to Pay Attention to His People
item.description: The activist Sonam Wangchuk is leading protests to demand more autonomy for India’s remote Ladakh region, which shares borders with China and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Tauseef Mustafa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sonam Wangchuk, an activist from the Ladakh region of India, is leading protests to demand more control over how the area is used and governed.

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi Died. But for Her, the ‘Bunga Bunga’ Scandal Lives On.
item.description: The woman at the center of revelations of bacchanals at the former Italian prime minister’s villa is still fighting a court case, and a negative public image, 14 years later.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Davide Monteleone for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He messed up my life,” Karima el-Mahroug says of Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister who died last year.

item.title: How Palestinians Are Roadblocked in the West Bank
item.description: Driving in the Israeli-occupied West Bank is an incredibly different experience depending on who you are. Ben Hubbard, international correspondent for The New York Times, rode along on two bus trips, one for Israelis, the other for Palestinians, that tell a story of separate and unequal roadways.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Rebecca Suner and James Surdam

item.title: Boot Found at Everest Could Be From Sandy Irvine, Who Vanished 100 Years Ago
item.description: When Sandy Irvine went on a pioneering expedition to Mount Everest’s summit in 1924, he and his partner vanished. The recent discovery may shed light on the ill-fated adventure.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:credit: Noel E. Odell/Royal Geographical Society, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The last known image taken of George Mallory, left, and Sandy Irvine. The two men vanished while trying to be the first to reach the summit at Mount Everest in 1924.

item.title: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s Former First Minister, Dies at 69
item.description: He led the Scottish National Party twice, guiding it from a fringe political group into a powerful electoral force in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Ben Stansall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Alex Salmond in 2014 speaking to supporters in advance of the referendum on Scottish independence. That effort propelled his career, and he was the nation’s first pro-independence first minister.

item.title: Secret Documents Show Hamas Tried to Persuade Iran to Join Its Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The Times reviewed the minutes of 10 meetings among Hamas’s top leaders. The records show the militant group avoided several escalations since 2021 to falsely imply it had been deterred — while seeking Iranian support for a major attack.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Adam Rasgon and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house in Kibbutz Kfar Aza, Israel, last December that was among those attacked on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: Fitch Ratings Issues Warning About France’s Finances
item.description: A rating agency’s warning about the country’s ballooning debt comes as the prime minister tries to push an austerity budget through a divided Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Teresa Suarez/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Fitch Ratings warned that it could lower France’s sovereign credit rating if the government’s budget plans fall apart.

item.title: Love Lessons
item.description: The editor of the long-running Modern Love column reflects on two decades of working with people’s deeply personal stories.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Jones

item.title: In British Columbia, a Political Party’s Collapse Echoes an Earlier Election
item.description: The end of a coalition of Conservatives and Liberals over 70 years ago led to a surprising election result and reshaped the province’s politics.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

item.title: Israeli Strikes on Northern Gaza Kill at Least 20, Aid Workers Say
item.description: Israel’s military said it was “operating with great force” against Hamas and allied groups and issued new evacuation orders, as it also continued its campaign in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:credit: Omar Al-Qattaa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mourning on Saturday over the bodies of Palestinian relatives killed overnight in the Jabaliya area of the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Boris Johnson Makes a Case for Trump’s Return, and Perhaps, His Own
item.description: In his memoir, “Unleashed,” the former prime minister is “optimistic” about the possibility that Donald J. Trump could regain the White House.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The epigraph for Boris Johnson’s memoir is “Hasta la vista, baby,” an Arnold Schwarzenegger line from a “Terminator” film.

item.title: Canada Tightens Immigration Policy And Leaves Thousands in Limbo
item.description: Canada has long had one of the world’s most open immigration policies. Now, faced with a growing popular backlash, it’s changing the rules.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Willms
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: International students and others line up for busses, in Brampton, Canada, on Monday. Canada’s post-pandemic experiment at large-scale import of foreign students and temporary workers is heading for a rapid overhaul.

item.title: Is Israel’s Invasion of Lebanon Legal? Here’s What International Law Says.
item.description: Explaining the issues of sovereignty, self-defense and humanitarian safeguards.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath on Friday of an overnight strike in the Ras el-Nabaa neighborhood in central Beirut that killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 100.

item.title: How South Korea’s Dogs Became Members of the Family
item.description: They have become pampered family members in South Korea, which has the world’s lowest birthrate and where much of the population lives alone.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: O Hanna, a teacher, at Dogkingabout, a “total dog care center” in Seoul.

item.title: Rise of the Dragons: Fire-Breathing Drones Duel in Ukraine
item.description: Drones are getting another new twist: Soldiers attach canisters to them to create weapons capable of spitting out molten metal that burns at 4,400 degrees.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian drone operators preparing to test a new drone last month in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Lebanon’s Leader Calls on U.N. for Cease-Fire as Beirut Searches for Airstrike Survivors
item.description: Rescuers dug through rubble in Beirut as the caretaker prime minister implored the United Nations to adopt a resolution calling for an “immediate” truce between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Ephrat Livni and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath in Ras el-Nabaa, in central Beirut, on Friday after overnight Israeli airstrikes killed at least 22 people and wounded more than 100.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, U.S. Journalist Imprisoned in Russia, Will Publish a Memoir
item.description: The memoir, which will cover his time in prison and Russia’s move toward autocracy, will be published by Crown, an imprint of Penguin Random House.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter and Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich was freed as part of a complex prisoner swap after 16 months in a Russian prison.

item.title: Northern Lights Animate Night Skies Around the Globe: Photos
item.description: An outburst from elevated solar activity created conditions on Thursday that kept people’s eyes glued to evening views all over the Northern Hemisphere.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The light of the aurora borealis shining brightly over what are known as the Kissing Trees, near the town of Kinghorn, in Fife, Scotland.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Is Awarded to Nihon Hidankyo For Its Efforts to Rid of Nuclear Weapons
item.description: Toshiyuki Mimaki, the chairman of Nihon Hidankyo, which was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, said his foremost wish was to “please abolish nuclear weapons while we are alive.”
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: United States Army
item.media:description: The devastation of Hiroshima in the aftermath of the atomic bombing in 1945, in a photo released by the United States government.

item.title: Israeli and U.S. Defense Ministers Discuss Israel’s Expanding Military Operations in Mideast
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, on Thursday, the Pentagon said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Kevin Lamarque/Reuters
item.media:description: Defense Minister Yoav Gallant of Israel at the Pentagon in June. Mr. Gallant and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been scheduled to meet in Washington this week, but the visit was postponed.

item.title: Lebanon’s Leader Calls for U.N. Resolution on an ‘Immediate’ Cease-Fire
item.description: It was the latest attempt by Najib Mikati’s embattled government to bring an end to the violence that has killed thousands and displaced nearly one million.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Lebanese Prime Minister's Press
item.media:description: Lebanon’s caretaker prime minister, Najib Mikati, speaking on Friday, in a handout photo provided by the Lebanese prime minister’s press office.
